items.message: The Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes are high, but currently falling, following an extremely wet November. Flooding will continue to affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, the car park at Tesco and Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. Only minor flood impacts are expected in Barnham. Only isolated showers are forecast over the next five days. The Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes should slowly fall all week. However, through Shripney and Bersted minor flood impacts will still continue until the weekend. It will likely take a fortnight of dry weather for river levels to return nearer to normal. River levels will remain sensitive to future rainfall. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Shripney Lane. We continue to routinely clear grilles through Barnham, including at the Trading Post and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 11:00 02/12/2022.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message: The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.94 m and is currently stable. The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.03 m and is slowly falling by 5 mm an hour. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, but this is increasingly unlikely with the continuing dry weather. We are continuing to pump at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station. Dry weather is forecast for the next five days from today, Thursday 01/12/2022. This flood alert remains in force due to remaining water on the moors but with the dry weather, the situation will improve. We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are busy clearing weed screens and checking the condition of banks and spillways. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 13:00 on Friday, 02/12/2022, or as the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
The forecast is dry for the next few days.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.22 m and falling very slowly. Water enters Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45 m, but this is increasingly unlikely with the continuing dry weather. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 5.38 m and is falling by approximately 9 mm per hour. We are currently pumping to reduce the water in the moor as quickly as possible. Dry weather is forecast for the next five days from today, Thursday 01/12/2022. This flood alert remains in force due to the amount of water still on the moor, but with the dry weather, the situation will improve. We will continue to monitor the situation, and our incident response staff are busy clearing weed screens and checking the condition of the spillways. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 13:00 on Friday, 02/12/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are beginning to slowly fall on the River Glyme particularly around Woodstock as a result of persistent rainfall last week. Water may remain on roads and farmland however further flooding is not currently expected. The forecast today is isolated light showers are possible. We expect river levels to remain high on the River Glyme over the next few days. 
We are monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated this evening, 02/12/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are steadily falling on the River Ray as a result of persistent rainfall last week. Further flooding of roads and farmland is not expected, however water may remain out of banks especially in the areas around Islip. The forecast today is isolated light showers are possible.
We are monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated this evening, 02/12/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but steady at the Brimscombe river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall, consequently flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Elmore to Sharpness. Other locations that may be affected include Chalford, Leonard Stanley and Cambridge. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days and are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated by 5:00pm on 02/12/22 or as the situation changes.

River levels continue to remain high at the Briantspuddle river gauge on the River Piddle as a result of the heavy rainfall over the weekend.  River levels are starting to fall but still pose a flood risk between Alton Pancras and Wareham.  We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are out checking defences.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded.  Please refer to the local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on Friday, 02/12/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Leach from Northleach to Mill Lane near Lechlade
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are beginning to slowly fall on the River Leach as a result of a period of sustained rainfall over the past few weeks. Further flooding of roads and farmland is not expected, however water will remain high especially in the areas around Lechlade.  The forecast today is isolated light showers are possible.
We are monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated this evening, 02/12/22, or as the situation changes.
